The process of converting cellulose into short-chain alcohols is a critical component of biomass valorization. In this study, we utilized an anion-cation co-directed hydrothermal method and wet impregnation to synthesize a hierarchical MFI zeolite with isolated Ni and W sites. We employed linear correlation analysis to evaluate the influence of pore size, site accessibility, and acidity on product selectivity. Balancing hydrogenation and acidic sites on the catalyst enhanced retro-aldol condensation and hydrogenation during cellulose conversion. Surface acidic sites accelerated glucose retro-aldol condensation, while micropore acidic sites aided in ethylene glycol hydrogenolysis. The close proximity of Ni and W facilitated high selectivity and yield of ethanol through bimetallic synergy. This research presented a novel strategy for preparing hierarchical zeolites with isolated metal sites and provides clarity on the cooperative roles of active sites in Ni-W bimetallic catalysts for cellulose conversion. Graphical Abstract Key words Biomass Biofuels Bimetallic catalyst Metal@zeolite Hierarchical zeolite Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The escalating demand for environmentally-friendly chemicals, coupled with societal concerns, has catalyzed the advancement of green and sustainable chemistry. Cellulose, a major component of biomass, holds promise as a potential source for various downstream chemical products, thus attracting widespread attention [1–6]. In 2008, Ji et al. pioneered the direct conversion of cellulose to ethylene glycol using a Ni-W2C/AC catalyst via a one-pot method, paving a new pathway for cellulose conversion [7]. Short-chain alcohols derived from cellulose serve as renewable low-carbon fuels. These not only originate from eco-friendly sources but also satisfy the high energy demands. Consequently, researchers have increasingly focused on efficient methods for converting cellulose into short-chain alcohols. As illustrated in Scheme 1, the process of converting cellulose into short-chain alcohol encompasses several stages: hydrolysis, isomerization, condensation of retro-aldol, hydrogenation, and further hydrolysis. Initially, cellulose undergoes hydrolysis to yield glucose, which can subsequently be isomerized to fructose. Both glucose and fructose are then hydrogenated to produce sorbitol and mannitol, respectively. Glucose is subjected to transaldolase condensation, resulting in the formation of glycolaldehyde and erythritol. These compounds are further hydrogenated to yield glycol and ethanol. In contrast, fructose is transformed into dihydroxyacetone and glyceraldehyde, which are hydrogenated to produce 1,2-propylene glycol [8–11]. Liang et al. engineered a highly active Ni/ZSM-5 catalyst, demonstrating its efficacy in the efficient conversion of cellulose to hexanol [12]. Ding et al. investigated a cost-effective Ni2P catalyst designed to enhance both cellulose hydrolysis and glucose hydrogenation, yielding C6 alcohol as the primary product (sorbitol and mannitol) [13]. Ji et al. analyzed their previous work and found that the addition of metal Ni on the acidic supports was beneficial to produce short-chain alcohols [14,15]. Zhao et al.'s study demonstrated that the bimetallic catalyst, comprising metal W and group Ⅷ metal on various supports, exhibited a synergistic effect of dual catalytic sites in cellulose conversion. The W component and Ni facilitated C-C bond cracking and hydrogenation, respectively. Furthermore, the selectivity of short-chain alcohols using bimetal catalysts surpassed that of mono-metal catalysts [16,17]. Previous research has indicated that the target product can be obtained with enhanced selectivity by regulating key competing steps in the cellulose conversion to short-chain alcohols catalytic network. This is achieved through the synergistic action of hydrogenated and acidic metal double catalytic sites [18–20]. To effectively control the aforementioned key steps, numerous bifocal catalysts possessing both hydrogenation activity and acidic sites have been proposed for cellulose conversion [21–23]. Among the various catalyst systems, the nickel-tungsten bimetallic catalyst system demonstrates superior catalytic efficiency [24–26]. However, a more comprehensive analysis of the bimetallic synergies within nickel-tungsten bimetallic catalyst systems is required to further enhance their potential for catalyst improvement. These studies include: (i) an examination of Ni as the active site for hydrogenation and its catalytic mechanism; (ii) an analysis of W as the active site for C-C bond breaking and its mechanism; (iii) a study of the synergistic effect, proportion, and structure-activity relationship of Ni and W metals in Ni-W bimetallic catalysts; and (iv) the design and development of high-efficiency nickel-tungsten bimetallic catalysts. Herein, it is imperative to devise bimetallic multifunctional catalysts that facilitate the separation of Ni and W sites, while also investigating their individual impacts and synergistic effects. The graded zeolite structure, capable of accommodating different metal sites, is particularly well-suited for both large and small molecules involved in cellulose degradation. In our prior studies, we successfully accomplished a one-pot synthesis of a metal catalyst constrained within the zeolite skeleton, with the metal strategically positioned within both the zeolite framework and its micropores [27]. The creation of multistage pore channels on a zeolite-based metal catalyst framework presents an optimal solution for the multi-step conversion of cellulose. In this study, we employed an anion-cation co-directing hydrothermal method to synthesize hierarchical zeolite with metal confined within the framework and micropores. Subsequently, a second metal was introduced into the mesopore via wet-impregnation. This two-step synthesis procedure facilitated the location of multiple metal sites at different positions. Detailed characterizations were conducted to identify the chemical properties of the active sites in a series of Ni-W bimetallic catalysts. In the cellulose conversion test, it was found that the location and chemical environment of the Ni and W sites significantly influenced product selectivity. A linear correlation analysis was utilized to investigate the effects of pore size, site availability, and acidity on selectivity. This study provided insight into how the different active sites in the Ni-W bimetallic catalyst synergistically affected the conversion of cellulose. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials and reagents Tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 40 wt% aqueous solution) was purchased from Shanghai Bide Medical Technology Co., Ltd. Tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, AR), Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O), Ammonium Metatungstate ((NH4)6H2W12O40·xH2O), 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid, Cellulose microcrystalline (C6H10O5)n), Glucose (C6H12O6), Fructose (C6H12O6), Mannitol (C6H14O6), Sorbitol (C6H14O6), Butane-1,2-diol (C4H10O2), Glycidaldehyde (C3H6O3), Methylglyoxal (C3H4O2), Glycerol (C3H8O3), 1,3-Dihydroxyacetone (C3H6O3), 1,2-Propanediol (C3H8O2), Hydroxyacetone (C3H6O2), Ethylene glycol (CH2OH)2, Ethanol (C2H5OH), were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Deionized water was purchased from Hangzhou Wahaha Group Co. Ltd. All the reagents were used without any pretreatment. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Synthesis of hierarchical porous Ni@MFI and W@MFI supports The Ni@MFI and W@MFI supports were synthesized by anion-cation co-directing hydrothermal method. In the first step, TEOS (6 g) and TPAOH (3.59 g, 40 wt% aq) were mixed with deionized water (5.00 g) in a 50 mL centrifuge tube. Then, 1,3,5-Benzenetricarboxylic acid (0.26 g in 5.00 g of deionized water) was added to the mixture. The mixture was stirred magnetically at 450 rpm and maintained at 60 °C in an oil bath for 12 hours. Following this, saturated Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O solution and/or (NH4)6H2W12O40·xH2O solution was rapidly incorporated into the heated aged silica gel. The mixture was then thoroughly blended through intense mechanical vibration for a few seconds. The mixture was heated in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave (HTG-50-SS2, Anhui CHEMN Instruments Co. Ltd.) and at 170 °C for 24 h. The zeolite was collected after filtration, washing with water, and drying at 105 °C. The zeolite thus obtained was calcined at 550 °C in air for 2 h with a heating ramp of 3 °C/min. According to the content of metal added, these supports were named 4Ni@MFI (content of Ni was 4 wt%) and 4 W@MFI (content of W was 4 wt%), respectively. In addition, the hierarchical porous support S-1 was synthesized as above but without any metal addition. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Ni/W@MFI and W/Ni@MFI supported-catalysts The supported-catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation method. The supports (2 g) and corresponding amount of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O or/and (NH4)6H2W12O40·xH2O were mixed with water (200 g) while being magnetically stirred at 45 °C for 24 h. After elimination of the water by rotary evaporation and drying at 80 °C, the solid sample was calcined at 550 °C in air for 2 h with a heating ramp of 3 °C/min. According to the different supports selected, the samples were named 4 W/4Ni@MFI (content of W was 4 wt% on the support 4Ni@MFI), 24 W/4Ni@MFI (content of W was 24 wt% on the support 4Ni@MFI), 4Ni/4 W@MFI (content of Ni was 4 wt% on the support 4 W@MFI) and 4Ni20W/4 W@MFI (content of Ni was 4 wt% and W was 20 wt% on the support 4 W@MFI), respectively. All catalysts mentioned above were reduced at 600 °C for 2 h with a heating ramp of 1 °C/min under an H2 flow of 100 mL/min before use. 2.3 Catalyst characterization JEOL Model JEM-2010 LaB6 TEM system was used to collect transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images. The samples for TEM analysis were prepared by dipping the carbon-coated copper grids into an ethanol solution of the sample and allowed to dry under ambient conditions. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis for catalysts was carried out on TTR-III X-ray diffractometer (Japan). The monochromatized radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) used Cu-Kα. The 2θ ranges were 5°-65°. Temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) was performed on an automatic chemical adsorption instrument (VDsorb 91i, Quzhou Vodo Instrument Co., Ltd). The catalyst was first reduced by 30 sccm 5 %H2/Ar for 2 h at 500 °C. After cooling down to 40 °C and purged with Ar for 1 h, the TPD was processed under 30 sccm Ar flow with ramping rate of 10 °C/min. NH3-TPD of the samples was detected by the fully automatic chemisorption instrument (VDsorb 91i, Quzhou Vodo Instrument Co., LTD, China). Standard process: 0.1 g sample with a diameter of 40–60 mesh was filled into the quartz reaction tube, and the two ends were stuffed with quartz cotton to prevent the sample from blowing out and blocking the tube. TCD temperature was set as 80 °C. NH3/He (1.05 %/98.95 % by volume) gas flow was 40 sccm. Then the samples were pretreated in a flowing He atmosphere at 200 ℃ for 60 min to remove residual moisture and adsorbed impurities on the sample surface. After cooling to 80 ℃, He was switched to NH3/He for 60 min to ensure the adsorption capacity of NH3 reached saturation of the sample. Then the gas path was switched to He to remove the NH3 physically adsorbed on the surface of the sample. After the TCD signal was stable, the temperature was heated up to 500 ℃ with the heating rate of 10 ℃/min. Meanwhile, the desorption signal of NH3 during the heating process was recorded. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Scientific, England) spectrometer. Test conditions: ultimate vacuum of analysis chamber: 5 × 10−10 mbar; monochromatic X-ray source: Al kα 150 W, beam spot 500 μm; energy resolution and sensitivity: when the FWHM of Aɡ3d5/2 is 0.6 eV, the intensity is greater than 1,600,000 cps. The C1s photoelectron peak with a binding energy of 284.8 eV was used as a reference to correct the spectrum. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of samples were measured at 77 K (Tristar II 3020 M, Micromeritics, America). Sample pre-activation procedure: degas at 120 ℃ for 2 h and then activate at 300 ℃ for 2 h. The sample weight after activation was 0.1 g. According to the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm, the surface area and pore size distribution of the catalyst were calculated by BET and BJH methods, respectively. The ATR-FTIR spectra of the samples were detected by the Fourier Transform Infrared Microscope (Nicolet iN10, America). The sample was pre-dried and dehydrated for testing and analysis. The Raman spectra of the samples were detected by the Laser Raman spectrometer system (LabRamHR, Jobin Yvon, France). The UV–vis spectra of the samples were detected by the Ultraviolet-visible-near-infrared spectrophotometer (SOLID3700, Shimazu, Japan). The Kubelka-Munk function (F(R∞)) for infinitely thick samples was used to convert reflectance measurements into equivalent absorption spectra. 2.4 Catalyst test The hydrogenation of cellulose microcrystalline (C6H10O5)n was conducted in a 25 mL NSC-type reactor sourced from Anhui CHEMN Instruments Co. Ltd. The procedure involved the dispersion of 100 mg of cellulose microcrystalline and 100 mg of catalyst in a 10 g distilled H2O solution. Prior to the reaction, the reactor underwent three purges with hydrogen, followed by charging with hydrogen to the appropriate pressure. This was then stirred at a speed of 800 r/min using magnetic force. Upon completion of the reaction, the reactor was immersed in cold water to cool down to room temperature. Subsequently, the gas within the instrument was collected using a gas bag. Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was isolated via filtration. Subsequent analysis of the solution was conducted using a Shimadzu high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) system, which included a Biorad Aminex HPX-87H column and a RID detector. Calibration for quantification was achieved using commercially available standards. The gas product was detected in real time by a gas chromatograph (Panna A91 Plus GC), equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID, utilizing a PQ column) and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD, employing a TDX-01 column). Product yields were determined based on the carbon mass, utilizing the following equations. Product yield ( % ) = Mass of product × carbon mass fraction Mass of feedstock input × carbon mass fraction × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterizations of the catalysts A hydrothermal method, utilizing an anion-cation co-directing approach (organic polyacid anion, quaternary amine base cation), was developed to facilitate the one-step synthesis of hierarchical porous zeolites doped with heteroatoms under weakly acidic conditions, as depicted in Scheme 2. In conventional zeolite synthesis, a quaternary amine base is frequently employed as an organic structure-directing agent (OSDA) under alkaline conditions [27]. This strategy proposed the addition of an additional organic polyacid as a secondary OSDA for mesopore formation. Trimeric acid was introduced during the initial hydrolysis of TEOS, followed by the addition of a metal source. No mineralizing agents such as NaOH or HF were utilized. Ni@MFI, W@MFI, and pure silica zeolite meso-S-1 without additional metal were prepared as supports. Subsequently, supported-catalysts 4Ni20W/4 W@MFI, 4Ni/4 W@MFI, 4 W/4Ni@MFI, and 24 W/4Ni@MFI were obtained by loading different metals onto the supports using the wet impregnation method. In a typical process, the metal-2 added during the hydrolysis step was presumed to be located within the zeolite support (referred to as support-metal), while the metal-1 added during the impregnation step was situated on the surface or mesopores of the zeolite (referred to as loaded-metal). By employing this strategy, two distinct metal species were separated and dispersed within different locations within the zeolite. The specific surface area (SBET), pore volume and pore diameter of M1/M2@MFI catalysts prepared by two OSDAs and metal-free mesoporous S-1 were determined by nitrogen physical desorption isotherm. Fig. 1A, Figure S1 and Table S1 are shown. For comparison, we synthesized an ordinary microporous pure silica S-1 with a single OSDA (TPAOH). S-1 exhibited type I isotherm characteristics and was a typical microporous material. In contrast, meso-S-1 showed a combination of type I and type IV isotherms, typical of multistage pore structures. In addition, the addition of metal-1 during impregnation or metal-2 during hydrolysis did not change the layered porous structure of mesoscopic S-1. The XRD patterns of the catalysts are presented in Fig. 1B. All M1/M2@MFI catalysts and meso-S-1 displayed characteristic peaks associated with typical MFI-type zeolites, it was viable to prepare the MFI zeolite using the co-directing method. No characteristic peaks of Ni or NiOx species were detected on 4Ni@MFI, nor were there any W or WOx species on 4 W@MFI. This indicated that the metal addition during the initial hydrolysis step was uniformly dispersed without accumulation. However, all three W- supported catalysts, 4Ni20W/4 W@MFI, 4 W/4Ni@MFI, and 24 W/4Ni@MFI, displayed characteristic peaks of WOx at 40.6° and 44.1°, indicating that the W- supported catalysts tended to form aggregates. Furthermore, figure S2 presents the TEM morphology and grain size of the catalysts. On the supported-catalysts, distinct metal particles could also be observed. Notably, M1/M2@MFI and meso-S-1 showed significantly increased grain sizes, suggesting that trimesic acid could enhance the crystallization process of MFI zeolite and facilitate the formation of larger crystals. The structure of M1/M2@MFI was also studied by ATR-FTIR, as well as the second derivative curves, as shown in Fig. 2A and S3. All samples showed typical MFI characteristic vibration peaks. The characteristic peaks at 800 cm−1 and 1225 cm−1 were the characteristic vibration peaks of zeolite with MFI topology. Especially, in 4 W@MFI and 4Ni@MFI, the bands of antisymmetric T-O-T vibration perturbed by cations were presented in the region of 930–975 cm−1 [28]. This indicated that some of the Ni and W metals added to the crystals were chemically adjacent to the zeolite skeleton. Fig. 2B and S4 depicted the UV–vis DRS spectrum for each sample. The absorbance of all M1/M2@MFI was markedly elevated in comparison to that of S-1 and meso-S-1, a phenomenon attributable to the presence of metal species. The spectra of all supported catalysts exhibited an absorption peak ranging from 200 nm to 220 nm, which corresponds to the ligand-metal charge transfer (LMCT) O2--Ni2+ for NiO species and O2--W6+ for WOx species (Figure S5) [29]. The band observed around 250–280 nm in the W-support catalysts was attributed to tetrahedron or octahedron W species. Moreover, the peaks at 260 nm in 4Ni20W/4 W@MFI could also be ascribed to the formation of Ni-W-O species [30]. The optical energy absorption edge of the samples was derived from diffuse reflectance UV–vis absorption spectra, as depicted in Figures S6 and S7. The W-supported catalysts, specifically 4Ni/4 W@MFI and 4 W@MFI, exhibited similar absorption edge energies, primarily influenced by the W species present in the zeolite. As the W content increased, the absorption edge energy of the catalysts progressively converged towards the standard WOx [31]. Interestingly, a significant shift was observed in the absorption edge energy of 4Ni20W/4 W@MFI, potentially due to the synergistic effect of the Ni-W bimetallic system. Fig. 2C presents the UV-Raman spectra of each sample at λex= 325 nm. While all M1/M2@MFI catalysts preserved the approximate peak of MFI zeolite, the fine characteristic peaks of MFI zeolite were obscured following metal loading. The three W supported-catalysts also displayed WOx characteristic peaks at 690 nm and 880 nm, aligning with XRD characterization. The loaded-W tended to form aggregates that covered the zeolite surface. The structure of M1/M2@MFI is illustrated in Fig. 2D. XPS analysis revealed that W species existed in two forms: W6+ and a lower oxidation state, Wδ+. The peaks at 36.0 eV and 38.2 eV on the W4f7/2 and W4f5/2 spectra respectively, correspond to W6+, while the peaks at 31.4 eV and 33.6 eV were associated with Wδ+ [32]. This suggested that W species predominantly existed as WOx, yet could be readily reduced to Wδ+ within the surface and mesoporous pores. As the W species load increases, there was a corresponding rise in the ratio of W6+ to Wδ+. This could be attributed to the spontaneous aggregation of surface W species into larger particles, which made the outer layer more susceptible to reduction to Wδ+, while the inner layer of WOx remained stable. Fig. 3B shows the XPS spectrum of Ni 2p. The binding energy at 852.9 eV and 870.3 eV were corresponding to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of Ni0 species, respectively. The characteristic peaks at 855.5 eV and 873.0 eV were attributed to Ni2+. In addition, peaks at 863.3 eV and 880.8 eV belonged to satellite peaks [33,34]. Ni species presented within the zeolite in two forms: metallic Ni and NiOx. When loaded alone (4Ni/4 W@MFI), Ni species were evenly distributed and remained in their oxidation state. However, during bimetallic co-loading (4Ni20W/4 W@MFI), some Ni species retained their metallic form due to interaction with W, leading to the agglomeration of WOx into particles that were tightly bound to certain Ni atoms. This distinctive electronic environment effectively inhibited the oxidation of Ni. We also conducted a comparative analysis of the O 1 s XPS spectra for the M1/M2@MFI catalyst. The characteristic peak at 531.1 eV was associated with surface hydroxyl oxygen (OOH) [35], while the peak at 533.3 eV corresponded to the Si-O structure (OOSi) within the zeolite framework. Upon loading W onto the catalyst, OOH emerged on the surface, originating from hydrogen doping. During the reduction process, hydrogen molecules interacted with surface lattice oxygen, leading to the formation of surface oxygen vacancies. Subsequently, the -OH group associated with Wδ+ produced a surface W-OH species, which neutralized the system's overall charge, ensuring electrical neutrality [36]. The concentration of OOH serves as an indicator of the number of oxygen vacancies presented on the catalyst surface. Based on the above discussion, the catalyst mesoporous structure consisted of disordered irregular mesopores formed by secondary anion OSDA and interstitial mesopores formed by eutectic. These mesoporous pores had the ability to disperse metals, thereby enhancing mass transfer during the reaction. When W and Ni were simultaneously loaded onto the scaffold, WOx particles bound to the loaded-Ni. This bimetallic interaction served to prevent the surface Ni from undergoing oxidation. Post-metal loading, the catalyst exhibited defects, oxygen vacancies, and unsaturated oxidation sites. The hydrogenation active sites of M1/M2@MFI were investigated using H2-TPD spectroscopy. For 4 W@MFI and 4Ni@MFI, H2 desorption peaks were observed at 435 ℃ (for support-Ni) and 521 ℃ (for support-W), respectively. The H2 desorption process for loaded-metals was more intricate, with a peak at 393℃ corresponding to the H2 desorption from loaded-Ni. Both 24 W/4Ni@MFI and 4 W/4Ni@MFI exhibited two peaks at 201 °C and 310 °C, which were attributed to W6+ and Wδ+ species of loaded-W. While loaded-Ni demonstrated superior hydrogen activation capability, this ability diminished as the accessible H2 sites decreased due to the bimetallic effect. In contrast, loaded-W tended to aggregate into particles, with the outer layer or defects acting as hydrogen adsorption sites while the interior remains inactive. The availability of active sites was found to decrease with an increasing W load. The computational procedure was detailed in Table S2. The acidity active sites of M1/M2@MFI were investigated using NH3-TPD. Fig. 4B illustrated that the NH3 desorption curves for all catalysts display a primary desorption peak in a mild temperature region, accompanied by a secondary peak at a higher temperature. These curves underwent peak deconvolution, revealing that the NH3 desorption peak at 165 ℃ corresponds to the weak acid site of the catalysts, while the peak at 290 ℃ corresponds to the medium acid site. The predominant source of the catalyst's acidity was identified as WOx within the zeolite. Similarly, the acid content of the catalyst was determined based on the NH3-TPD curve, as presented in Table S3. An increase in loaded-W content resulted in an increase in surface W-OH sites and acidic sites, thereby enhancing the catalyst's acidity. M1/M2@MFI served as bifunctional catalysts, possessing both acid centers and active component centers. 3.2 Catalytic reactions and structure-activity relationship The catalysts were evaluated for their efficacy in the hydrogenation of cellulose at various temperatures. The resulting product distribution is depicted in Figs. 5 and 6. Upon near-complete conversion of cellulose, the products predominantly comprised C6, C4, C3, and C2 molecules. Specifically, C6 primarily consisted of glucose, fructose, and hexitol; C4 was chiefly composed of 1,2-butylene glycol; C3 mainly contained 1,3-propylene glycol, 1,3-dihydroxyacetone, pyruvic aldehyde, hydroxyacetone, glyceraldehyde, and glycerol; whereas C2 was primarily made up of ethanol, ethylene glycol, and glycolaldehyde. The final product distribution was found to vary depending on the specific catalyst used and the reaction temperature. The hexitol, primarily sorbitol, depicted in Fig. 5 was synthesized via the hydrogenation of glucose (Scheme 1, step R1). The highest yield of hexanol was achieved using the 4Ni/4 W@MFI catalyst. This was attributed to the ease with which the Ni site on the catalyst could be accessed by glucose and its rapid hydrogenation. However, due to the competitive advantage of the hydrogenation reaction, subsequent retro-aldol condensation or isomerization reactions were inhibited, resulting in a decrease in C4+C3+C2 products. Conversely, the 4Ni20W/4 W@MFI catalyst yielded the lowest hexanol due to the interaction between the Ni site and the W particles. This interaction diminished the accessibility of the Ni active site, thereby limiting its hydrogenation capacity. This general trend aligned with the H2-TPD results. The C3 compounds identified were the result of fructose, which was an isomerization product of glucose (Scheme 1, step R3). Within the catalyst, glucose underwent isomerization to yield fructose. This was then followed by a hydrogenation process that produced 1,2-propylene glycol as the primary product. Other C3 compounds such as 1,3-dihydroxyacetone, pyruvic aldehyde, hydroxyacetone, glyceraldehyde, and glycerol were derived from intermediates or byproducts. The low yield of C3 compounds across all catalysts suggested that the presence of WOx species in the catalyst impedes the isomerization process by promoting the retro-aldol condensation of glucose. These findings were consistent with previous reports [18]. Glucose produced C2 and C4 products through the inverse aldol condensation reaction (Scheme 1, step R2). This process necessitated the breaking of a C-C bond to form glycolaldehyde, which could then be transformed into glycol and ethanol. A reduced yield of C2 products was noted at 4 W/4Ni@MFI, potentially due to an insufficient number of catalyst acid sites limiting C-C bond breakage. The superior ethylene glycol yield on 24 W/4Ni@MFI may be due to the insufficient microporous acidity to promote the hydrogenolysis of ethylene glycol to ethanol. In contrast, the 4Ni20W/4 W@MFI catalyst promoted the hydrolysis of small molecules, yielding 80 % ethanol. WOx provided ample acidic active sites to break C-C bonds in glucose and competitively inhibited the hydrogenation and isomerization reactions of glucose. The Ni-W bimetallic site of co-impregnation maintained a balance between the acidic site and the hydrogenation site of the catalyst, enabling the reverse aldehyde condensation reaction and the subsequent glycolaldehyde hydrogenation reaction to proceed simultaneously and rapidly produce C2 products. And WOx acid site in zeolite micropores further facilitated the hydrogenolysis reaction of ethylene glycol to ethanol. Additionally, the structure of the hierarchical zeolite effectively protected the metal sites, thereby demonstrating exceptional cyclic stability of the catalyst (Figure S8). To elucidate the selectivity of competitive reactions, including hydrogenation, isomerization, and inverse aldol condensation, and to delve deeper into the influence of catalyst physicochemical properties on product selectivity, specific structural and reactional data were selected as variables for a Pearson product-moment correlation coefficient analysis, as depicted in Fig. 7. The R factor was determined using the following equation: R = 1 n − 1 ∑ i = 1 n ( X i − X ̅ σ X ) ( Y i − Y ̅ σ Y ) Darker blue or light green indicated stronger positive or negative linear dependence respectively, while intermediate color indicated weak dependence. Meanwhile, Table 1 showed the distribution of products across various catalysts. The hydrogenation activity of the catalysts, directly related to the formation of hexanol, was represented by the ratio of hexitol C 2 + C 3 + C 4 + Fructose . The ratio of C 2 + C 4 C 3 + Fructose reflected the ability of the catalysts to catalyze retro-aldol condensation of glucose. The ratio of Ethanol Ethylene glycol and the selectivity of ethanol reflected its hydrolysis ability. For the catalyst pore size, a larger pore size enhanced the mass transfer process of glucose, thereby increasing the accessibility to hydrogenation sites. However, excessively large pores led to an increase in the yield of hexanol, a byproduct of hydrogenation, which resulted in the suppression of the competitive retro-aldol condensation pathway and a decrease in the target product ethanol yield (4Ni/4 W@MFI). Regarding the balance between the acidic and hydrogen sites of the catalyst, stronger catalyst acidity and moderate hydrogenation activity were conducive to the formation of retro-aldol condensation products. Supported-WOx affected the overall acidity of the catalyst, and the acidic sites on the surface or within the mesopores were the main sites for glucose retro-aldol condensation. When the catalyst acidity was weak, it could not promote the retro-aldol condensation competition to inhibit the glucose isomerization reaction (4 W/4Ni@MFI). As for the anchoring sites of the catalyst's acidic and hydrogen sites, WOx species in the zeolite micropore channels were the main active sites for ethylene glycol hydrogenolysis, and only having mesoporous acidic sites was not conducive to small molecule hydrogenolysis reactions (24 W/4 W@MFI). Catalysts with both microporous and mesoporous acidic sites were more suitable for the production of ethanol from cellulose (4Ni20W/4 W@MFI). In light of the aforementioned discussion, the catalysts demonstrated optimal catalytic activity and selectivity towards ethanol only when a balance was achieved between hydrogenation sites and acid sites. This balance signified the equilibrium between retro-aldol condensation and hydrogenation in the catalytic conversion of cellulose, with the relative balance significantly impacting the overall conversion process. Furthermore, the positioning of hydrogenation and acid sites on the catalyst also modulated this reaction balance. If the hydrogenation site was situated on the catalyst surface or mesopore, or if the catalyst's hydrogenation capacity was overly strong, the hydrogenation reaction became dominant, leading to a sharp increase in C6 products. Therefore, to enhance retro-aldol condensation, hydrogenation sites should be confined to micropores to limit accessibility, or bimetallic sites should be formed to reduce their hydrogenation capacity. Acidic sites should be present in both microporous and mesoporous regions. The WOx species on the surface could provide acidity to promote the retro-aldol condensation of glucose and inhibit glucose isomerism. The microporous WOx species serves as the primary active site for the hydrogenolysis of small molecule ethylene glycol, providing an essential acidic environment for the high-yield preparation of the target product ethanol. 4 Conclusion In this study, we employed an anion-cation co-directing hydrothermal method in conjunction with wet-impregnation to synthesize hierarchical zeolite featuring separated metal sites within both micropore and mesopore. The hydrothermal method facilitated the introduction of metal into the zeolite framework and micropore, while the wet-impregnation technique allowed for the loading of metal into the mesopore. We utilized linear correlation analysis to investigate the influence of pore size, site availability, and acidity on selectivity. The acidic site in the mesopore was found to promote retro-aldol condensation, thereby cleaving the C-C bond of glucose. Conversely, the acidic site in the micropore facilitated the hydrogenolysis of ethylene glycol to ethanol. The hydrogenation site in the mesopore led to the hydrogenation of glucose to hexitol, while the hydrogenation site in the micropore was essential for the hydrogenation of unsaturated intermediates. The multimetallic 4Ni20W/4 W@MFI catalyst exhibited an optimized synergistic effect, maintaining a balance between the hydrogen and acid sites of the catalyst and achieving a high yield of biofuel ethanol. This study offered a novel method for synthesizing hierarchical zeolite with separated metal sites and enhanced our understanding of how different active sites in Ni-W bimetallic catalysts synergistically affect cellulose conversion. coredata.dc:description: The process of converting cellulose into short-chain alcohols is a critical component of biomass valorization. In this study, we utilized an anion-cation co-directed hydrothermal method and wet impregnation to synthesize a hierarchical MFI zeolite with isolated Ni and W sites. We employed linear correlation analysis to evaluate the influence of pore size, site accessibility, and acidity on product selectivity. Balancing hydrogenation and acidic sites on the catalyst enhanced retro-aldol condensation and hydrogenation during cellulose conversion. Surface acidic sites accelerated glucose retro-aldol condensation, while micropore acidic sites aided in ethylene glycol hydrogenolysis. The close proximity of Ni and W facilitated high selectivity and yield of ethanol through bimetallic synergy. This research presented a novel strategy for preparing hierarchical zeolites with isolated metal sites and provides clarity on the cooperative roles of active sites in Ni-W bimetallic catalysts for cellulose conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Accurate location of Ni and W active sites in hierarchical zeolite catalyst for the conversion of cellulose to alcohols
